questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient presents with dyspnea on exertion and occasional palpitations. A chest X-ray is performed, revealing the cardiac silhouette. Study the image provided and answer the following question. Which of the following statements regarding the heart's position, size, and borders on the chest radiograph is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: The right heart border is formed primarily by the right ventricle.

options.label: B
options.text: The left atrium primarily forms the left heart border.

options.label: C
options.text: The cardiothoracic ratio (CTR) is considered normal if it is less than 0.5 on a PA chest X-ray.

options.label: D
options.text: The right atrium and the left ventricle mainly form the inferior border of the heart.

questions.correct_answer: C. The cardiothoracic ratio (CTR) is considered normal if it is less than 0.5 on a PA chest X-ray.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents with mild exertional dyspnea. Clinical examination reveals a fixed split S2 and a systolic ejection murmur at the left upper sternal border. A chest X-ray shows the following features. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.correct_answer: A. Partial Anomalous Pulmonary Venous Connection (PAPVC)

questions.text: A 31-year-old man presents with dyspnea, orthopnea and fatigue. The radiological images are attached below. Based on the given information, which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Etiology

Often idiopathic, can be secondary to infection, radiation, or autoimmune diseases

Pathophysiology

Thickened, fibrotic, and calcified pericardium restricting cardiac filling

Clinical Presentation

Dyspnea, fatigue, chest pain, signs of right heart failure

CT Findings (IOC)

• Thickened pericardium (>4 mm), often calcified

• Pericardial effusion may be present

• Dilation of inferior vena cava and hepatic veins

Other Imaging

Cardiac MRI- To measure pericardial thickness

questions.text: A 3-day-old newborn is brought to the emergency department with marked central cyanosis. On examination, his heart rate is 160 bpm, respiratory rate is 65 breaths/min, and oxygen saturation is 80% on room air. A chest radiograph is performed, showing cardiomegaly with a characteristic "egg on a string" appearance. If an echocardiogram is conducted, which of the following echocardiographic findings would be most consistent with the suspected condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Ventricular septal defect with overriding aorta

options.label: B
options.text: Single great artery arising from the heart

options.label: C
options.text: Parallel great vessels with the aorta anterior and slightly to the right of the pulmonary artery

options.label: D
options.text: Abnormal pulmonary venous connections to the right atrium

questions.correct_answer: C. Parallel great vessels with the aorta anterior and slightly to the right of the pulmonary artery
questions.explanation:
D-Loop TGA (dextro-transposition of the great arteries)

L-Loop TGA (Congenitally Corrected)

Pathology
  • The aorta originates from the right ventricle and the pulmonary trunk from the left ventricle, creating two parallel circulatory circuits.
  • This condition is life-threatening unless a shunt, like a patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) or septal defect, is present to allow blood mixing.
  • Congenitally corrected TGA (ccTGA) is characterized by both atrioventricular and ventriculoarterial discordance, a condition referred to as "double discordance."

X-ray
  • Cardiomegaly
  • "Egg on a string" appearance
  • Narrow mediastinum
  • Increased pulmonary vascular markings
  • Mesocardia or levocardia
  • Straight left heart border
  • Abnormally straight vascular pedicle
  • Possible bulge along upper left cardiac border

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with gradually worsening dyspnea and reduced exercise tolerance over the past month. The chest X-ray is given below. Regarding this patient's condition, which of the following statements is INCORRECT?

options.label: A
options.text: "Oreo cookie" sign will be seen on lateral view on Chest X Ray

options.label: B
options.text: The patient typically shows abrupt enlargement of cardiothoracic ratio

options.label: C
options.text: Seldinger technique is employed for management of this condition

options.label: D
options.text: An Echocardiogram is a better modality than CT to confirm the diagnosis

questions.correct_answer: B. The patient typically shows abrupt enlargement of cardiothoracic ratio
questions.explanation:
Imaging Modality

Radiological Findings

Notes

Plain Radiograph

• Globular enlargement of cardiac shadow

• "Water bottle" configuration

• Widening of the subcarinal angle

• "Oreo cookie" sign on lateral view (Option A)

• Serially enlarging cardiothoracic ratio

• Usually visible when >200 mL of fluid present

• May show signs of cardiogenic pulmonary edema in severe cases

Echocardiography

• Anechoic separation of pericardial layers

• Fluid first appears posteriorly in supine patients

• Depth of effusion correlates with volume

• Method of choice for diagnosis (Option D)

• Can detect as little as 50 mL of fluid

• Allows assessment of hemodynamic impact

CT

• Fluid density material surrounding the heart

• Pericardial thickness >3-4 mm is abnormal and suggestive of effusion

• Often used to clarify cause rather than confirm diagnosis

• Can help differentiate from other conditions (e.g., hemopericardium)

questions.text: A 68-year-old female patient presents to the emergency department with complaints of increasing shortness of breath over the past few weeks and occasional palpitations. She has a history of hypertension and was diagnosed with mitral stenosis five years ago. A chest X-ray is performed, and the radiologist notes specific findings. Based on the chest X-ray findings, which of the following features is most indicative of the condition observed?

options.label: A
options.text: Elevation of the left main bronchus

options.label: D
options.text: Cardiomegaly with a normal heart border

questions.correct_answer: A. Elevation of the left main bronchus

questions.text: A 60-year-old male with hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and a smoking history presents for a routine evaluation. He has no symptoms but is concerned about cardiovascular health due to a family history of heart disease. Which score is used to assess coronary artery disease risk?

A 58-year-old male with a history of hypertension and recent long-distance travel presents with sudden chest pain and dyspnea. A Computed Tomography Pulmonary Angiography (CTPA) is performed, and the findings are given below. Which of the following statements regarding the findings associated with the given condition is FALSE?

options.label: A
options.text: Hampton Hump indicates hemorrhage and necrotic lung tissue in pulmonary infarction.

options.label: B
options.text: The Westermark Sign shows regional oligemia due to reduced blood flow.

options.label: C
options.text: Chang Sign shows an enlargement of the right descending pulmonary artery.

options.label: D
options.text: Palla Sign indicates enlargement of the right descending pulmonary artery.
